When he was governor of Texas, George W.
Bush described the life-and-death decision on clemency as the most agonizing part of being governor.
Last Friday, Kenneth Lee Boyd became the 1,000th prisoner to be put to death since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976.
A jury in North Carolina found him guilty of the 1988 murder of his estranged wife and father-in-law.
Earlier last week, Virginia Governor Mark Warner commuted the death sentence of Robin Lovitt to life without parole.
That marks the 230th time a convicted killer has been granted clemency in the modern era of the death penalty.

The spotlight turns now to California, where Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger considers the fate of Stanley ""Tookie"" Williams, a founding member of a notorious Los Angeles street gang who's scheduled for execution a week from today for the murder of four people in 1979.
In prison, Williams redeemed himself, his supporters say, in campaigns against drugs and crime and gangs.
In this hour we'll explore how governors make their clemency decisions.
What process do they follow?
What are the legal and moral considerations?
Do political consequences come into play?
We talk with two former governors who faced this Godlike decision.
And we welcome your phone calls.
What factors should governors consider on clemency?
